results.title: A Sundance With Brains and Guts, Disemboweled and Otherwise
results.abstract: This year’s festival featured lots of scares, a parade of bodies (and body parts) and a haunted, haunting postcolonial tale set in New York.

multimedia.caption: Anna Diop in “Nanny,” one of the standouts in this year’s lineup.

results.title: ‘The Exiles’ and ‘Nanny’ Win Top Prizes at Sundance
results.abstract: A documentary revisiting dissidents from the Tiananmen Square massacre and a horror film about an undocumented domestic worker took the U.S. Grand Jury prizes at the festival.

multimedia.caption: Christine Choy in the directors Ben Klein and Violet Columbus’s “The Exiles,” which won the U.S. Grand Jury Prize for documentary at the Sundance Film Festival.

results.title: Kamau Bell: Bill Cosby Is Key to Understanding America
results.abstract: The comic and commentator discusses his new documentary, “We Need to Talk About Cosby,” and what Cosby’s story reveals about the “two runaway forces of oppression in America.”
des_facet: We Need to Talk About Cosby (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: The comic and commentator W. Kamau Bell is known as someone who is willing to have difficult conversations, he said. But the one about Bill Cosby was tougher than most.

results.title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: This month’s picks include a grim western teeming with bloodthirsty outlaws, humans fighting an alien invasion and more.

multimedia.caption: Stephen Moyer in “Confession.”

results.title: He’s a Doctor. He’s an Actor. He’s an Indie Heartthrob.
results.abstract: How does Anders Danielsen Lie of “The Worst Person in the World” juggle careers in acting and medicine? “This has been my ongoing identity crisis,” he said.
des_facet: The Worst Person in the World (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Anders Danielsen Lie works full time as a doctor in Oslo. Add in acting and “it’s just a lot of hustle making the calendar work out.”
multimedia.copyright: David B. Torch for The New York Times

results.title: Producers Guild Nominations Keep ‘Dune’ in Play
results.abstract: The group’s choices often influence what academy voters do at the Oscars. That’s why the omissions of “Spider-Man: No Way Home” and “No Time to Die” may be significant.
des_facet: Summer of Soul (... Or, When the Revolution Could Not Be Televised) (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Timothée Chalamet and Rebecca Ferguson in “Dune,” the highest-grossing film to be nominated by the Producers Guild.
multimedia.copyright: Chia Bella James/Warner Bros., via Associated Press

results.title: ‘Futura’ Review: Youth, Italian Style
results.abstract: Three filmmakers travel Italy in the midst of the pandemic, listening to young people talk about their fears and aspirations.

multimedia.caption: Some of the young Italians who are interviewed in “Futura,” a documentary by Pietro Marcello, Francesco Munzi and Alice Rohrwacher.

results.title: ‘Compartment No. 6’ Review: Strangers on a Russian Train
results.abstract: A young Finnish woman embarks on a journey of self-discovery that takes her (and you) through richly detailed and surprising terrain.

multimedia.caption: Seidi Haarla in “Compartment No. 6,” directed by Juho Kuosmanen.

results.title: ‘The Fallout’ Review: The Unexpected Effects of Trauma
results.abstract: Jenna Ortega stars as a teenager coping with the aftermath of a school shooting in this grounded and compassionate look at adolescent grief.

multimedia.caption: Jenna Ortega, right, with Julie Bowen in “The Fallout.”

results.title: Sundance Canceled? Don’t Tell These Partygoers.
results.abstract: The film festival went virtual again this year. But that didn’t stop some veteran attendees from having a good time in Park City anyway.

multimedia.caption: The absence of films and celebrities did not keep revelers away from Sundance. Here, the bar scene at the St. Regis Deer Valley last week.
multimedia.copyright: Lindsay D'Addato for The New York Times

results.title: Carol Speed, Vixen of the Blaxploitation Era, Dies at 76
results.abstract: In the mid-70s, thanks to two beloved B movies, she had a moment in the spotlight and enjoyed celebrity status in the Black press.

multimedia.caption: The actress Carol Speed in the early 1970s. Her fresh-faced prettiness provided a dramatic contrast to her roles as a demon in “Abby” (1974) and a prostitute in “The Mack” (1973).

results.title: Family of Slain ‘Rust’ Cinematographer Weighs Wrongful-Death Lawsuit
results.abstract: Lawyers for the family of Halyna Hutchins filed a petition in New Mexico to appoint a representative who will consider whether to file a suit.

multimedia.caption: Halyna Hutchins, a cinematographer, was shot and killed on the set of “Rust” by a gun that the actor Alec Baldwin was practicing with on the set.

results.title: ‘The Ice Age Adventures of Buck Wild’ Review: A Franchise Thaws
results.abstract: The latest installment in this animated film series replaces nearly all of its celebrity voice performers with close proxies.
des_facet: The Ice Age Adventures of Buck Wild (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Buck, voiced by Simon Pegg, in “Ice Age: The Adventures of Buck Wild.”

results.title: Moses Storm and the Case for Pretentious Modern Stand-up
results.abstract: In his new special, the comic claims he has no agenda, but his jokes and stories about poverty cohere into trenchant commentary. Why are themes out of fashion?

multimedia.caption: Moses Storm in his new special, “Trash White.”

results.title: Woody Allen’s ‘Rifkin’s Festival’ Is Opening in U.S. Theaters
results.abstract: The movie is showing after years of resistance to Allen’s work in the United States following renewed attention to Dylan Farrow’s allegations of sexual abuse.

multimedia.caption: “Rifkin’s Festival,” directed by Woody Allen and starring Gina Gershon and Wallace Shawn, will be viewable in the United States on Friday.

results.title: Watch the Throne: How Joel Coen Came to Make ‘The Tragedy of Macbeth’
results.abstract: When your whole filmmaking career has been one of unexpected twists and turns, how do you surprise yourself? Adapt a Shakespeare play.

multimedia.caption: Joel Coen during production of “The Tragedy of Macbeth.” He came to the play “as an amateur,” he said. “I’m still an amateur.”

results.title: Directors Guild Nominations Focus on Veterans Like Jane Campion and Steven Spielberg
results.abstract: The films of all five contenders are also up for Producers Guild Awards, suggesting that they will make up the top tier of best-picture nominees at the Oscars.

multimedia.caption: Jane Campion, with the associate producer Phil Jones, on the set of “The Power of the Dog.”

results.title: ‘A Taste of Hunger’ Review: A Relentless Pursuit of Perfection
results.abstract: A husband and wife pour everything into their restaurant in a quest for a Michelin star, heedless of the other dimensions of their lives.

multimedia.caption: From left, Katrine Greis-Rosenthal and Nikolaj Coster-Waldau in “A Taste of Hunger,” directed by Christoffer Boe.

results.title: Writers Guild Nominations: ‘Don’t Look Up,’ ‘Licorice Pizza’ and More
results.abstract: The group’s contenders can be predictive of the Oscars but several films, including “Belfast” and “The Power of the Dog,” weren’t eligible.

multimedia.caption: Leonardo DiCaprio and Jennifer Lawrence in “Don’t Look Up,” with a screenplay by Adam McKay.

results.title: ‘The Conductor’ Review: Seizing the Baton
results.abstract: In this biographical documentary, Marin Alsop recounts how she became the first woman to lead a major American orchestra.

multimedia.caption: Marin Alsop, center, is the subject of “The Conductor.”

results.title: The End of ‘Fight Club’ Was Cut in China. The Pattern Goes Back Decades.
results.abstract: The 1999 cult classic starring Brad Pitt and Edward Norton is not the only foreign film to be altered for audiences in mainland China.

multimedia.caption: Brad Pitt in a scene from “Fight Club,” released in 1999. A version of the film on a streaming service in China features a different, less violent ending.

results.title: ‘La Soga Salvation’ Review: A Very Inferior Set of Thrills
results.abstract: The sequel to the 2010 thriller “La Soga” trades the original’s pointed commentary on crime and corruption for something more generic.

multimedia.caption: Manny Perez, left, and Chris McGarry in “La Soga Salvation.”

results.title: ‘They/Them/Us’ Review: Working Out the Kinks
results.abstract: In this dramatic comedy, two divorced 40-somethings gamely experiment with B.D.S.M.

multimedia.caption: Joey Slotnick and Amy Hargreaves in “They/Them/Us.”

results.title: ‘Clean’ Review: Taking Out the Trash
results.abstract: Adrien Brody plays a community do-gooder with a not-so-pristine past in this action film directed by Paul Solet.

multimedia.caption: Adrien Brody in “Clean.”

results.title: ‘Sundown’ Review: Stuck in the Shallow Waters of Acapulco
results.abstract: In this Michel Franco film, a family group escapes to the beach in Acapulco, the onetime sun-baked paradise that has become an epicenter of violence.

multimedia.caption: Tim Roth in “Sundown,” by Michel Franco.

results.title: Their Characters Are Stuck, but the Filmmakers Are Anything But
results.abstract: Sujata Day and Agam Darshi, who hadn’t met until their movies were done, each portray women of South Asian descent who stay home to care for parents.

multimedia.caption: Sujata Day, left, and Agam Darshi in Los Angeles. Their films treat similar subject matter very differently.
multimedia.copyright: Rozette Rago for The New York Times

results.title: John Stamos on Bob Saget and the Many Stages of Their Friendship
results.abstract: In an interview, the “Full House” star recalls everything from early clashes to Cyrano-like support, as well as the last time he saw his former co-star.

multimedia.caption: Bob Saget, left, in John Stamos’s trailer during production of “Fuller House” in 2020.

results.title: Worried About the Health of Cinema? Sundance Has Good News for You.
results.abstract: From surprising found-footage documentaries to “Get Out”-influenced dramas and that Lena Dunham title, this year’s virtual festival has a lot to like.

multimedia.caption: A scene from the found-footage documentary “Fire of Love,” directed by Sara Dosa.

results.title: Peter Dinklage Calls Disney’s ‘Snow White’ Remake ‘Backward’
results.abstract: The actor said on a podcast that he was stunned to learn that “Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs” would be made into a live-action film. Disney said Tuesday that it was “consulting with members of the dwarfism community.”
des_facet: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (Movie)

multimedia.caption: “I was sort of taken aback,” Peter Dinklage said of finding out that Disney was remaking “Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.”
multimedia.copyright: Joel C. Ryan/Invision, via Associated Press

results.title: Alec Baldwin Seeks Dismissal of ‘Rust’ Lawsuit
results.abstract: The suit was filed by a script supervisor who was just feet away from the film’s cinematographer when the actor fatally shot her on the set.

multimedia.caption: The church set where Halyna Hutchins, a cinematographer, was shot and killed last year with a gun the actor Alec Baldwin had been told had no live ammunition.

results.title: The Black List, Founded in Hollywood, Expands Into Theater
results.abstract: The project seeks to connect undiscovered writers with industry gatekeepers.

multimedia.caption: Franklin Leonard founded the Black List to call Hollywood’s attention to undiscovered writers. Now his organization is expanding into theater.
multimedia.copyright: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times

results.title: Jenna Ortega Gets Her Thrills From Radiohead and ‘Paris, Texas’
results.abstract: The scream queen talks about her latest film, “The Fallout” on HBO Max, dancing in public and driving in the dark.

results.title: ‘Beyond the Infinite Two Minutes’ Review: Hello, It’s You
results.abstract: In this time-travel comedy, a cafe owner and his friends discover a portal that allows them to see two minutes into the future.

multimedia.caption: Kazunari Tosa, left, and on the computer screen, in “Beyond the Infinite Two Minutes.”

results.title: Mahershala Ali Finally Gets the Leading Role He Deserves
results.abstract: After a string of supporting performances, he steps into the spotlight as not one but two main characters in the sci-fi drama “Swan Song.”

multimedia.caption: “I always felt like a bit of a late bloomer,” Mahershala Ali said.
multimedia.copyright: Chanell Stone for The New York Times
